elements.title: Business Overview and RFJ Auto Acquisition

data.value: Sonic Automotive, Inc.
One of the largest automotive retailers in the U.S. operating three main segments: Franchised Dealerships, EchoPark, and Powersports.

Franchised Dealerships Segment (new and used vehicles, Fixed Operations, F&I), EchoPark Segment (used vehicles, F&I only), and Powersports Segment (new/used powersports vehicles, Fixed Operations, F&I).
Acquisition of RFJ Auto Partners, Inc. and its subsidiaries on December 6, 2021.
33 automotive retail locations in seven states and a portfolio of 16 automotive brands; integration added 22 stores to Franchised Dealerships and 11 stores to EchoPark.
The pandemic affected global economic conditions and automotive supply chains, impacting vehicle inventory and production.
The company plans to acquire dealerships and open new stores, targeting consolidation in the retail automotive industry.
Acknowledges the fragmented nature of the industry and expects further consolidation, leveraging attractive acquisition opportunities.
Acquisition activity is contingent on the availability of financing and any contractual provisions that may restrict such activities.
Plans include opportunistic repurchase of Class A Common Stock or outstanding debt to maintain a targeted capital structure.

elements.title: SONIC AUTOMOTIVE, INC. - Process Execution & Brand Portfolio Optimization

data.value: SONIC AUTOMOTIVE, INC.
Maximize Asset Returns Through Process Execution via standardized operating playbooks that drive process improvements, enhance the guest experience, and create operational efficiencies.
Belief in organic growth opportunities by offering a more favorable buying experience and refining business processes.

Long-term growth strategy focused on acquiring desirable businesses in strategic markets with favorable population growth and vehicle registration trends. The company actively evaluates acquisition opportunities and other strategic transactions to strengthen or diversify its brand portfolio.

data.key: First Table - U.S. Vehicle Industry Volume Comparison 2021-2022
data.value: Categories include 'U.S. industry volume - Retail new vehicle', 'U.S. industry volume - Fleet new vehicle', and 'U.S. industry volume - Total new vehicle'. Data shows retail volume increased from 13.1 million in 2021 to 17.0 million in 2022 (with an -11% change noted, although the percentage seems inconsistent with the numbers), fleet volume increased slightly from 1.9 to 2.0 million (5% growth), and total new vehicle volume declined from 15.0 to 13.7 million (9% decline). Summary: This table breaks down U.S. vehicle industry volumes by segment for the two years.
The 2023 new vehicle industry volume is estimated between 14.0 million (an increase of 2.2% compared to 2022) and 15.0 million vehicles (an increase of 9.5% compared to 2022).

Potential influences include ongoing supply chain disruptions due to the COVID-19 pandemic, inventory availability of new and used vehicles, interest rates, changes in consumer confidence, availability of consumer financing, production levels, shifts in manufacturer incentives, and timing issues due to natural disasters or other unforeseen circumstances.

data.key: Second Table - New Vehicle Sales and Revenue Performance Comparison 2021-2022
data.value: This table presents several metrics: Retail new vehicle revenue increased from $4,993.4M in 2021 to $5,622.6M in 2022 (a change of 629.2, or 13% increase). Fleet new vehicle revenue declined from $124.6M to $99.4M (a 20% drop). Total new vehicle revenue increased by 12% to $5,722.0M. Additionally, unit sales for retail new vehicles saw a minor increase, while fleet unit sales declined significantly, and revenue per unit metrics improved. Gross profit margins improved from 9.0% to 11.7%, with an increase of 270 basis points.

Metrics reported include Retail new vehicle revenue, Fleet new vehicle revenue, Retail and Fleet gross profits, unit sales figures, revenue and gross profit per unit values, and gross profit percentages for retail, fleet, and combined new vehicles.

data.value: Revenue increased by 22% to $3,140M in 2022 compared to $2,572M in 2021. Gross profit shifted from $6M in 2021 to a loss of $63M in 2022. Unit sales decreased by 4%, while revenue per unit increased by 28%. Gross profit as a percentage of revenue fell from 0.2% to -2.0% (a decline of 220 basis points).

data.key: Same Store Wholesale Vehicle Financial Metrics
data.value: Revenue for same store wholesale vehicles increased by 3% to $256.9M in 2022 compared to $249.2M in 2021. However, gross profit deteriorated sharply from $8.0M to a loss of $5.1M, representing an approximate decline of $13.1M. Unit sales declined by 21%, and revenue per unit increased by 30%. The gross profit margin dropped from 3.2% to -2.0% (a decline of 520 basis points).

The increase in revenue per unit was driven primarily by excess demand from dealerships and rental car companies in the wholesale auction market amid new vehicle inventory shortages. Conversely, the severe deterioration in gross profit was largely due to decreasing wholesale auction market prices throughout 2022.

data.value: Total F&I revenue

The table shows F&I (Finance & Insurance) revenue comparison between 2022 and 2021. Same market revenue decreased by 36% from $190.8M to $123.0M. New markets showed significant growth from $2.9M to $43.4M. Overall, total reported revenue decreased by 14% from $193.7M to $166.4M. The decline in same market revenue was partially offset by growth in new markets.

data.key: Retail Used Vehicle and F&I Performance Metrics Table Title
data.value: Retail Used Vehicle and F&I Performance Metrics

data.key: Retail Used Vehicle and F&I Performance Metrics Summary
data.value: This table presents retail used vehicle and F&I performance metrics comparing 2022 to 2021. Notable trends include a 4% increase in retail used vehicle revenue despite an 18% decrease in unit sales; a significant improvement in gross profit from a loss of $55.2M in 2021 to a profit of $44M in 2022; and a 50% increase in total retail used vehicle and F&I gross profit per unit. While F&I revenue decreased by 14%, the overall combined gross profit showed a positive trend with a 23% increase.

data.key: Same Market Retail Used Vehicle and F&I Table Title
data.value: Same market retail used vehicle and F&I

data.key: Same Market Retail Used Vehicle and F&I Table Summary
data.value: This table shows year-over-year comparison of retail used vehicle and F&I metrics between 2021 and 2022. Notable trends include overall declines in vehicle sales volume (-33%) and revenue (-19%), improvement in gross profit from -$56.8M to -$14.3M, an increase in revenue per unit by 22% despite lower sales volume, and a decrease in F&I revenue by 36%. Despite challenging conditions, total gross profit per unit increased by 21% from $1,741 to $2,109.

Reported retail used vehicle revenue increased approximately $84.2M (4%) due to a 26% increase in revenue per unit, partially offset by an 18% decrease in unit sales volume. Combined retail used vehicle gross profit and F&I revenue increased by approximately $32.3M (23%), driven by a 50% increase in gross profit per unit, attributed primarily to improved inventory acquisition costs from sourcing more from non-auction sources and expanding the inventory to include older, higher-margin vehicles.

elements.title: Debt Facilities Covenants and Dividend Restrictions

data.value: The 2019 Mortgage Facility includes standard representations, warranties, and covenants that restrict/incorporate provisions related to indebtedness, liens, dividend payments, capital expenditures, material dispositions, and acquisitions of assets. It specifically permits quarterly cash dividends on Class A and Class B Common Stock up to $0.12 per share, contingent upon no Event of Default and compliance with all financial covenants.

Excluding the 2019 Mortgage Facility, the weighted-average interest rate for outstanding mortgage notes increased to 5.14% as of December 31, 2022 (up from 3.50% in 2021) with a principal balance of approximately $302.6 million. These notes require monthly principal and interest payments, are secured by underlying properties, and include cross-default provisions with maturity dates from 2023 to 2033.

New and certain used vehicle inventories are financed through floor plan facilities. These facilities are arranged with manufacturer captive finance companies and a syndicate of manufacturer-affiliated finance companies and commercial banks, carrying variable interest rates (1.99% in 2022 and 1.06% in 2021). Manufacturer assistance amounts received and recorded as a reduction in cost of sales are also noted.

Non-compliance with covenants under the 2019 Mortgage Facility, 2021 Credit Facilities, floor plan agreements, and other Significant Debt Agreements could trigger defaults and acceleration of repayment obligations, causing cross-default situations across different debt obligations.

elements.title: SONIC AUTOMOTIVE, INC. RISK FACTORS - Item 1A. Risk Factors

data.value: The document outlines various risk factors that may adversely affect the business, financial condition, operations, cash flows and market performance of Sonic Automotive, Inc.

Investments in new business strategies, services, and technologies (including EchoPark and powersports businesses) are inherently risky. These investments may disrupt current operations, require significant management resources, and may not yield the expected returns.

The company's ability to execute its growth strategy and acquire new dealerships is limited by available capital, credit facility restrictions, interest rate increases, and the need for manufacturer consents. Limited liquidity and pledging of assets further constrain obtaining additional financing.
Future dealership acquisitions are contingent on obtaining lender and manufacturer approvals as well as securing necessary floor plan financing, which may limit the pace and scale of growth.

The document outlines risk factors related to growth through strategic acquisitions and brand development, particularly focusing on the challenges of integrating acquired dealerships with existing operations.
Failure to effectively integrate acquired businesses could adversely affect future operating results, with difficulties in assimilating operations, personnel, and management resources.
The actual financial condition and liabilities of acquired dealerships may not be determinable until after acquisition, increasing uncertainty over historical performance and future risks.
Risks include higher capital expenditures and operating expenses, challenges in entering new markets, potential undiscovered liabilities, and disruptions to ongoing business.
SONIC AUTOMOTIVE, INC.
Retail Automotive
Supply Chain, Economic, and Regulatory Risks
Global supply chain disruptions due to natural and man-made disasters, including the COVID-19 pandemic, armed conflict, adverse weather, and production delays affecting vehicle and parts inventory.
Reduced travel and economic activity, low inventory levels in 2022, increased sales prices and acquisition costs, with uncertain recovery timeline.

Exposure to various federal, state, and local laws (motor vehicle sales, leasing, finance, insurance, employment, environmental, etc.) and potential liabilities from non-compliance, including lawsuits, fines, and penalties.
Impact of Dodd-Frank Act regulations affecting automotive finance companies, including recommendations by the CFPB regarding dealer markup policies.

Increasing competition among automotive retailers and the use of the internet reduces our profit margins on vehicle sales and related businesses. Automotive retailing is a highly competitive business. Our competitors include publicly and privately owned dealerships, some of which are larger and have greater financial and marketing resources than we do. Many of our competitors sell the same or similar makes and models of new and used vehicles that we offer in our markets at competitive prices. We do not have any cost advantage in purchasing new vehicles from manufacturers due to economies of scale or otherwise. We typically rely on advertising, merchandising, sales expertise, customer service reputation and dealership location to sell new vehicles. In addition, our F&I business and other related businesses, which have higher margins than sales of new and used vehicles, are subject to competition from various financial institutions and other third parties. Our revenues and profitability could be materially adversely affected if certain state dealer franchise laws are relaxed to permit manufacturers to enter the retail market directly. Moreover, consumers are using the internet to compare pricing for vehicles and related F&I services, which may further reduce margins for new and used vehicles and profits for related F&I services. If internet-based new vehicle sales are allowed to be conducted without the involvement of franchised dealers, our business could be materially adversely affected. In addition, other dealership groups have aligned themselves with services offered on the internet or are investing heavily in the development of their own internet sales capabilities, which could materially adversely affect our business, financial condition and results of operations. Challenges to the business model of our franchised dealerships from manufacturers and the effect of companies entering into the automotive space may affect our ability to grow or maintain the business over the long term. Large and well-capitalized technology-focused companies have continued to enter into the automotive space in recent years. Companies including, but not limited to, Alphabet Inc., Amazon.com, Inc., Apple Inc., Lucid Group, Inc., Lyft, Inc., Rivian Automotive, Inc., Tesla, Inc. and Uber Technologies, Inc. may challenge the existing automotive manufacturing, retail sales, maintenance and repair, and transportation models. For example, Tesla, Inc. has been challenging state dealer franchise laws in many states with mixed results, but it has achieved success with new vehicle sales business model and its vehicles have been accepted by many consumers, even in states where dealer franchise laws appear to preclude such vehicle sales. In addition, other manufacturers whose new vehicles we sell have recently announced their intentions to implement an “agency” model of direct manufacturer to consumer sales in certain European markets. Although the long-term impact of the participation of vehicle manufacturers in direct sales is undetermined, these other large companies may continue to change consumers’ view on how automobiles should be manufactured, equipped, retailed, maintained and utilized in the future. Because these companies have the ability to connect with each individual consumer easily through their existing or future technology platforms, we may ultimately be at a competitive disadvantage in marketing, selling, financing and servicing vehicles. In addition, certain automobile manufacturers have expressed interest in or begun selling directly to customers. The franchised dealer’s participation in that potential future transaction type is unclear and our operations and financial results may be negatively impacted if the role of franchised dealers diminishes. Our dealers depend upon new vehicle sales and, therefore, their success depends in large part upon consumer demand for and manufacturer supply of particular vehicles. The success of our dealerships depends in large part on the overall success of the vehicle lines they carry. New vehicle sales generate the majority of our total revenue and lead to sales of higher-margin products and services such as finance, insurance, vehicle protection products and other aftermarket products, and parts and service operations. Our new vehicle sales operations are comprised primarily of luxury and mid-line import brands, which exposes us to manufacturer concentration risks. Although our parts and service operations and used vehicle and powersports businesses may serve to offset some of this risk, changes in automobile manufacturers’ vehicle models and consumer demand for particular vehicles may have a material adverse effect on our business. Our business is highly dependent on consumer demand and preferences. Events such as manufacturer recalls and negative publicity or legal proceedings related to these events may have a negative impact on the products we sell. If such events are significant, the profitability of our dealerships related to those manufacturers could be adversely affected and we could experience a material adverse effect on our overall results of operations, financial position and cash flows.
Manufacturers’ production capabilities and supply chain disruptions, including COVID-19 related delays, impact new vehicle inventory levels and sales volume.
Record low inventory levels in 2022 increased acquisition costs and reliance on proprietary appraisal systems and trade-ins, potentially reducing profitability if inventory remains limited.
Changes in consumer automotive lending conditions, including rising financing rates and tighter credit standards, may adversely affect vehicle unit sales and overall business performance.

Business may be adversely affected by import product restrictions, foreign trade risks, fluctuations in currency values, and changes in tariffs and duties, impacting profitability of foreign vehicle sales.
Operations are subject to supply chain disruptions, production delays, work stoppages, and inflationary pressures driven by political and socioeconomic instability in foreign markets.

Variability in customer demand, especially for fuel-efficient plug-in hybrid electric vehicles and battery electric vehicles, could disrupt inventory management and affect revenue from parts, service, and related warranty programs.

Dependence on manufacturer franchise or dealer agreements creates risk; termination or non-renewal of these agreements, or increased competition within given markets, may materially affect operations.
Uncertainty in the renewal and favorable terms of existing franchise and dealer agreements, which could materially affect business operations.
Manufacturers planning to implement an agency model in European markets may reduce inventory holding and adversely affect cash flows.
Failure to meet manufacturers’ customer satisfaction, financial, sales, or facility requirements may impair profitability and limit franchise acquisition opportunities.
Potential repeal or weakening of state dealer laws could lead to easier franchise terminations and renewals, increasing business risk.
Granting of new franchises or the ability of manufacturers to sell directly to consumers in existing markets may negatively impact revenues and profitability.
Sales volume and profit margins may be materially adversely affected by reductions or discontinuations of manufacturer incentive programs.
Dependence on manufacturers for sales incentives, customer rebates, financing/leasing incentives, warranties, dealer incentives, floor plan interest, advertising assistance, and support programs.
Risks associated with changes in captive finance companies' programs, underwriting criteria, and availability of consumer financing, potentially affecting vehicle demand.
Parts and service revenues are dependent on manufacturer warranty programs; changes in reimbursement rates for warranty-covered work could adversely affect margins.
Delays in vehicle deliveries due to supply chain disruptions, labor strikes, or production delays may limit sales, especially during new product introductions.
Bankruptcy of a manufacturer or related lender could lead to losses in receivables, termination of franchises, and potential impairment charges impacting financial results.

Manufacturer stock ownership restrictions may impair the company’s ability to maintain or renew franchise or dealer agreements. Certain agreements prohibit transfers without manufacturer approval, risking termination or non-renewal if ownership interests or voting power change.

The company faces significant indebtedness (approximately $3.0 billion) and relies on various credit facilities and lease arrangements. The ability to borrow depends on compliance with financial covenants and representations, and failure to do so could materially affect financial health and access to capital.
Insufficient funds may prevent repayment of a substantial portion of outstanding indebtedness when due, triggered by financial or operating covenant breaches or defaults.
Default on one debt instrument can result in cross default and acceleration of repayment obligations under other agreements.
Refinancing may be difficult or on unfavorable terms, compounded by the need for significant balloon payments at mortgage note maturities and reliance on subsidiary cash flows.
Use of hedging transactions, such as interest rate caps, may not fully mitigate financial risks related to interest rate fluctuations.
The ability to service debt relies heavily on cash flows from subsidiaries, which are not obligated to provide funds.

Our hedging transactions expose the company to risks such as counterparty credit risk, mismatches in hedge duration and amount, and potential mark-to-market losses affecting recorded stockholders’ equity.

Reforms and uncertainty regarding LIBOR, including its discontinuation and the transition to alternative benchmarks like Term SOFR, may adversely impact financial contracts, hedging strategies, and overall financial condition.
Approximately $116.0 million in LIBOR-based variable-rate mortgage notes extend beyond June 2023, and certain dealership operating lease agreements include LIBOR-based rent adjustments.
The dual class stock structure creates concentration of voting power, potentially affecting change of control events and influencing market price dynamics.

Our Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation and our Amended and Restated Bylaws make it more difficult for our stockholders to take corporate actions at stockholders’ meetings. In addition, stock options, restricted stock and restricted stock units granted under the Sonic Automotive, Inc. 2012 Stock Incentive Plan or the Sonic Automotive, Inc. 2012 Formula Restricted Stock and Deferral Plan for Non-Employee Directors and other obligations become immediately exercisable or automatically vest upon a change in control. Delaware law also makes it difficult for stockholders who have recently acquired a large interest in a company to consummate a business combination transaction with the company against its directors’ wishes. Finally, our franchise and dealer agreements allow the manufacturers the right to terminate the agreements upon a change of control of the Company and impose restrictions upon the transferability of any significant percentage of our stock to any one person or entity that may be unqualified, as defined by the manufacturer, to own one of its dealerships. The inability of a person or entity to qualify with one or more of our manufacturers may prevent or seriously impede a potential takeover bid. In addition, there may be provisions of our lending arrangements that create an event of default upon a change in control. These agreements, corporate governance documents and laws may have the effect of discouraging, delaying or preventing a change in control or preventing stockholders from realizing a premium on the sale of their shares if we were acquired. Potential conflicts of interest between us and our officers or directors could adversely affect our future performance. Our Chairman and Chief Executive Officer, David Bruton Smith, also serves as a director of Speedway Motorsports. Accordingly, we compete with Speedway Motorsports for the management time of Mr. Smith. Further, Mr. Smith, members of his family and certain trusts, the beneficiaries of which are members of the Smith family, directly and indirectly control a substantial majority of our voting stock. We will likely in the future enter into transactions with Mr. Smith, entities controlled by Mr. Smith and his family or our other affiliates. We believe that all of our existing arrangements with affiliates are as favorable to us as if the arrangements were negotiated between unaffiliated parties, although the majority of these transactions have neither been verified by third parties in that regard nor are likely to be so verified in the future. Potential conflicts of interest could arise in the future between us and our officers or directors in the enforcement, amendment or termination of arrangements existing between them. Our Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation and our Amended and Restated Bylaws designate the state and federal courts of Delaware as the exclusive forums for certain claims against the Company, which could increase the costs of bringing a claim or limit the ability of a stockholder to bring a claim in a judicial forum viewed by a stockholder as favorable. Our Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation and our Amended and Restated Bylaws provide that the Court of Chancery of the State of Delaware is the sole and exclusive forum for claims for (1) any derivative action or proceeding brought on behalf of Sonic (other than derivative actions brought to enforce any duty or liability created by the Exchange Act or the rules and regulations thereunder); (2) any action asserting a claim of a breach of, or based on, a fiduciary duty owed by any current or former director, officer or other employee of Sonic to Sonic or Sonic’s stockholders; (3) any action asserting a claim against Sonic or any current or former director, officer, or other employee or stockholder of Sonic arising pursuant to any provision of the General Corporation Law of the State of Delaware, our Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation or our Amended and Restated Bylaws; or (4) any action asserting a claim against Sonic governed by the internal affairs doctrine of the State of Delaware. Our Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation and our Amended and Restated Bylaws also provide that, unless the Board otherwise consents in writing, to the extent permitted by applicable law, the United States District Court for the District of Delaware shall be the sole and exclusive forum for resolving any complaint asserting a cause of action arising under the Securities Act of 1933, as amended (the “Securities Act”), the Exchange Act or any ancillary claims related thereto which are subject to the ancillary jurisdiction of the federal courts. The exclusive forum provisions of our Amended and Restated Certificate of Incorporation and our Amended and Restated Bylaws may increase the costs to bring a claim, discourage claims or limit a stockholder’s ability to bring a claim in a judicial forum that he, she or it finds favorable for disputes with the Company or the Company’s directors, officers or other employees. Such provisions may also discourage lawsuits against the Company or the Company’s directors, officers and other employees. The Delaware courts or the United States District Court for the District of Delaware may also reach different judgments or results than would other courts, including courts where a stockholder considering an action may be located or would otherwise choose to bring the action, and such judgments may be more or less favorable to us than to our stockholders.
The outcome of legal and administrative proceedings could materially adversely affect business.
Dependence on consumer demand; risk from downturns and supply chain disruptions.
Potential adverse effects from climate change legislation and greenhouse gas regulations.
Loss of key personnel could adversely affect operations.
The U.S. labor market experienced substantial tightening in 2021 and 2022, leading to increased labor costs and shortages of qualified employees, particularly for general managers and sales staff.
The market for qualified employees remains highly competitive, impacting our ability to attract and retain employees.
A lack of qualified management at potential acquisition candidates may limit our ability to consummate future acquisitions.
Natural disasters and adverse weather can disrupt business operations, particularly in states like California and Texas.
Due to concentration of property values at store locations, there is significant risk of property loss, which may not be fully covered by insurance.
Cyber-security incidents have increased and could compromise sensitive data, impacting our reputation and business operations.
Cyber-security breaches may result in legal claims or penalties, adversely affecting competitive position and financial condition.
Potential substantial withdrawal liability assessments if adverse events occur regarding the multiemployer pension plan contributions from certain dealerships.

Three dealership subsidiaries contribute fixed-dollar amounts to the AI Pension Plan, which is in critical status and projected to become insolvent by 2031, potentially triggering increased contributions.
Risk of governmental audits challenging tax positions, which could lead to higher income tax expenses, assessments, penalties, and potential litigation.
Exposure to material adverse effects on earnings if impairment of goodwill or other intangible assets occurs, resulting in significant non-cash impairment charges.

elements.title: SONIC AUTOMOTIVE, INC. NOTES TO CONSOLIDATED FINANCIAL STATEMENTS

data.value: In connection with the sale of dealerships, Sonic Automotive indemnifies buyers from certain liabilities post-sale (including environmental exposures and breaches of warranties). The indemnifications typically expire within one to three years. Environmental exposure was $4.0 million at December 31, 2021 and zero at December 31, 2022. Additionally, the company guarantees floor plan commitments for its 50%-owned joint venture, approximately $4.3 million as of December 31, 2022.

Sonic is involved in various legal and administrative proceedings, including regulatory investigations, customer litigation, employment-related lawsuits, contractual disputes, class actions, and actions by governmental authorities. Reserves for pending proceedings are recorded (approximately $0.4 million and $0.3 million in other accrued and long-term liabilities as of December 31, 2022, and $1.5 million and $0.3 million for 2021). The outcomes of these matters are uncertain and could have a material adverse effect on the company.

The provided table 'Comprehensive Income and Cash Flow Hedges Statement' displays figures from December 31, 2019 through December 31, 2022. It details cash flow hedges, defined benefit pension results, and overall comprehensive income (ranging from a loss of 2.1 million in 2019 to a gain of 1.6 million in 2022), along with additional disclosures regarding reclassifications and tax effects.
